There is a lot of snow in the winter and a lot of rain most of the year - but you should expect that living in New England.  The weather is really central to campus life - midnight snowball fights after the first snow, and everyone flocking outside the first day of spring when it's still only 45 degrees.

Spring and fall are perfectly lovely.  Summer is humid, but again, as to be expected.

Just buy a good pair of rain/snow boots - and you're set!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There is a bus line that will take you anywhere around the Upper Valley for free.  However, the only other public option is the Dartmouth Coach, which is 60 round trip to Boston multiple times a day or about 100 roundtrip to NYC a couple times a week.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It rains a lot, and in the winter that means it snows a lot, or sometimes it still rains. The summer is gorgeous, and the spring is nice too, but not a place for people who like sun.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: If you need one, which you probably won't because all undergraduates are required to have a laptop they're available, always.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Club Sports – I'm the VP of club field hockey, the newest club sport here and still a small program. Some of the club sports teams are treated really well, like varsity teams almost, including Rugby and Club Soccer. But those that don't have as much participation or such a great record are not treated that well, making it hard for them to expand and become successful.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Greek System – I love my sorority, and I do like going to the frats because I have friends there and I'm not the kind of girl that wants to dress up every night, let alone spend a lot of money on going-out clothes and drinks. However, I think it can be a little oppressive since its the only real social setting, and its a smaller group that participates so you feel like you know everyone and everyone knows everything about everyone. Its also highly male-centric since frats mostly host parties (only a couple local sororities are allowed to hold parties in their houses, since the national ones won't allow it).
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Oh It's Fine – I have no problem with the Dartmouth weather. Sure, it's not sunny all the time but that's what you should expect if you go to school in New Hampshire. Personally, as someone from Minnesota, I love the weather. The snow makes it look beautiful. And it's warm but not excessively hot other times of the year. Bring a coat and some gloves, but students are also pretty good at finding "warm-cuts" through the library to get from place to place.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: parking isn't really an issue… You can usually find spots on any of the streets,  at the fraternity houses, or the parking garage in town. It isn't that hard… But it isn't like it's something that makes the school great. Also, freshmen are not allowed to bring cars to school.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parkinf only costs $45 a term. The only downside is that the lot of kind of far from campus, maybe a mile walk. But still, you dont really need your car on campus anyway.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Cute Small Town – Hanover is one of the safest towns in one of the safest states.  There is almost no threat for crime and the dining off campus is pretty good.  Hanover does not offer much in terms of night life, but offers all the necessities to facilitate your on-campus life.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love it! Dartmouth weather is AMAZING! I'm from Texas and have never experienced a real winter. I have had so much fun sledding on the golf course, ice skating on the pond, and having snow ball fights on the green. A large, warm coat is definitely necessary. The other seasons are beautiful here too. It does rain quite a bit though. Grab an umbrella and some rain boots and you'll be fine.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Kinda Sucks – The student parking lot, A-Lot, is really inconvenient. It is nice to have a car though. Hanover is small, and I enjoy going to restaurants in different towns.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Love the outdoors, to snowboard, fish, swim, hangout.  All the seasons make it awesome.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There really isn't much parking for visitors besides parking meters.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Cozy, Welcoming Environment – Hanover is a small town, nestled within the trees of New Hampshire. Since its location is quite rural, it leaves students of Dartmouth College with a very home-like and comfortable environment. It seems as though everyone knows everyone. The sense of community is definitely a plus to the Big Green.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not Much to Do Outside of Campus – Although there is not much to do off campus, the programs and activities that are available are fun and interesting. If you ever get so bored on campus, it is very easy to get to Boston or another bigger city, but it is expensive.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Decent Computing – Since the school requires computer ownership, accessibility for lab computers isn't a top priority, but there are plenty of computers to use all over campus. The wireless network functions decently, but it won't work in some places. Most people prefer to connect through ethernet because it's a definite improvement. Printing can be a total pain; the GreenPrint system is temperamental at best. Computing Services is helpful, but be prepared to wait in an extremely long line for assistance. Otherwise, I don't have too many complaints.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Good Pick up System at Night – Good if you are caught at night and  not feelign well or  want a ride -  just call!
Free buses in town
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: mostly apple computers for use, but tech support focuses on microsoft. quite inconsistent.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The Bubble on the Hill – "The college on the hill" is located in Hanover, New Hampshire, a town that basically consists of Dartmouth College plus a main street. Despite its size, students find that Hanover offers a surprising variety of charming local restaurants, a farmer's market in the spring, free weekday shuttles to neighboring towns like West Lebanon, and some of the best gelato in the country. There is no nightlife, but Dartmouth's Greek scene more than makes up for it, and Boston and NYC are Dartmouth Coach bus rides away.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: On Campus – Living on campus is basically the only option.  There's literally nothing else in the surrounding area, and the public transportation system is limited at best.  Basically, useless.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus wide wireless is convenient and generally very reliable.  Students are required to have their own laptops, and financial aid can help with the cost. Computer services are decent. Desktop computers are available throughout campus for those who don't have their computers handy or working.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tradition sums up Dartmouth.  A lot of students joke that the old school alums refuse to let the school move past its ultraconservative, all-boys, animal house reputation.   I have had multiple friends visit Dartmouth, and they all look around bewildered at pretty much everything that goes on here.  Greek life is DOMINANT (about 70% of soph-seniors are in it... its a huge, huge deal), boys rule the school (literally and figuratively), there is a clear tension with gender and sexual assault issues (no matter whose "side" youre on), and there is a lot more binge drinking than one would expect at an ivy league.  The administration caters almost exclusively to alumni input, and there is a strooong disconnect between the students and the administration.  There are some awesome traditions, including DOC trips, orientation activities, green key, the homecoming bonfire, etc.  But traditions of the social life and "power structure" here are unlike anything I have heard of elsewhere.  It is very intense and it caters to the whims of white, affiliated, male athletes.  That is awesome and fun for some people and miserable for others.  Its just a preference thing.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Awful, With a Few Golden Days Thrown in – Do NOT be fooled by your tour day.  Most Dartmouth students are fairly convinced that admissions schedules the majority of tours for days they know will be beautiful.  The weather is crummy for the most of the time.  -30 days in the winter, lots of cloudy days, overall cold weather.  that said, there are some absolutely beautiful days in the late spring and early fall terms.  But for the most time, it is fairly miserable.  A lot of kids have "happy lamps" to make up for the lack of sunshine.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Depends on Where You're from – I come from a much milder climate, so it's a bit of an adjustment, especially during the wintertime.  Typical New England: long, cold winters, humid summers.  Late spring and early fall are both gorgeous.  The campus does not have very good drainage, though, so rain and snowmelt make the whole place flood.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It Can Be Done – A car is a really handy thing to have, as the public transit in the area leaves something to be desired-and Hanover can be sort of an isolating place.  The parking lots are not particularly convenient, though Greek houses have spaces available both for members and renting to non-members.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Can't Complain – The facilities are not quite as nice as some colleges, but everything is either in good shape or being renovated. The College has put lots of money into renovation projects, especially the dining hall that's supposed to be completed by Fall 2011.  We have a very expansive gym, a well-stocked library, and plenty of recreational buildings and spaces.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The D-Plan! The D-plan helped me get an awesome internship in NYC my Junior year.  Also, sophomore summer was the best summer of my life.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: We have a lot of computers in the library and a lot of printing stations.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Small Campus – Small campus so no need to have a car to get around. Not too many things to do off campus anyway except maybe go to west leb and go to walmart. The advance transit will take you to west leb though so again a car is not necessary. Parking is limited anyway.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Does Not Seem 300 Years Old – The Fitness Center is newly renovated and easily accessible to all of campus.  All of the athletic facilities are central to student life.  Baker-Berry Library is always clean and comfortable, as well as modern-looking, conducive to all study types.  Walking outside, the campus looks just as it did when Robert Frost and Dr. Seuss made their way to classes, but the administration is always remodeling and updating the facilities, making all students feel at home in a cutting-edge institution.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not an Issue – Yes, it's cold, but it doesn't bother me, and I'm from Georgia. There is a lot of snow, but the roads and sidewalks are always clear, and there are a lot of outdoor activities that make the cold bearable (like skiing, ice skating, snowball fights, etc.)
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: When you want transportation, it's there (a shuttle around campus and to a neighboring shopping center), but the campus is so small that everything you need is generally within a 20 minute walk. The transportation the the airport, a bus, seems expensive but is convenient.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The list of things that make Dartmouth different from other colleges is endless but two things are very important to Dartmouth life - they're part of the reason I chose to go here and why a Dartmouth college experience is so unique. First on the academic side is our infamous D-Plan. We're not like other schools with two semesters a year.  Instead, we have terms/quarters - the summer can count as a term (of course you don't have to stay there during summer but its easy to do so).  This means our terms are shorter and move by quicker BUT that allows for one of Dartmouth's main selling point - studying abroad/the D-Plan.  When I say we have TONS of programs, I'm not exaggerating.  If you're like me and don't like studying or speaking languages it doesn't matter - Dartmouth specifically has abroad programs to go along with our majors. They're taught by Dartmouth professors and you go with a bunch of other students interested in the same thing.  I don't know of any other college that gives you the opportunity to study on a quarter system and go abroad so often. Secondly there's our social scene, and by that I mean the main fun on Friday & Saturday nights.  Actually, on our campus the typical nights to go out are Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday (most people don't have class Tues or Thurs).  Our social scene is entirely based on the frat scene which works out perfectly.  I've never been turned away from a frat, and no I don't have the hookup that's just how Dartmouth is, and I've never paid for a drink or a concert.  It's that open and friendly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Don't Bother. Everything you need is within walking distance.  And if you really want to go to nearby malls, ask a friend.  They'll have a car.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Cute but Boring – The town seems adorable at first, but you can exhaust everything there is to do in less than three terms. The town likes the students and we make up a lot of the town, but once you've eaten everywhere and gone in every store, you're out of things to do.  There aren't really and franchise stores either so you're really going to miss McDonalds and Target.  There's a town nearby but it's not convenient to get to. You might get bored.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Bus, What? The busses are never on time, things are very far away and the weather is brutal. Best bet is to have a bicycle or to take everythign you need wherever you're going.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Freshmen Trips = AWESOME – When the freshmen first arrive on campus, almost ever single one participates in a freshman trip.  These include backpacking, hiking, biking, kayaking, cabin camping, organic farming, nature photography, rock climbing, and many other types of trips.  This was a great way to meet people before starting classes and trips were pretty small, so you really create a sense of family with your trip mates and trip leaders. The people I met on my trip are still my best friends on campus.  Also, the energy that comes from the upperclassmen when you first arrive on campus is outstanding; instead of hazing or the stereotypical hostility directed at freshmen, freshmen are greeted by excitement from all the other students for them to join the Dartmouth community.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Bring Your Own Computer, Don't Need a Printer – Having computer access on campus is extremely important and I would advise all incoming students to bring their own personal computer.  There are several computers on campus available if you do not have your own, but having a lap top makes life much more convenient (taking notes in class, being able to work other places besides the library, always having a computer available, etc.)  If you're experiencing trouble with your computer, you can take it to computer services where they are extremely helpful and friendly.  A printer, however, is not necessary.  There are several accessible printing stations all around campus, so you can print nearly anywhere at anytime (like on the way to class after grabbing breakfast in one of the dining halls).  The school even provides you with a printing account, so I would say owning your own printer is pretty unnecessary.  Finally, wireless access on campus is fantastic.  As with any network, it occasionally experiences a few glitches, but the problem never lasts long.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Gyms Are Terrible – athletics facilities are old and are in dire need of rennovation
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Gorgeous Autumns, Winter Wonderland – Dartmouth definitely gets all four seasons, but the two definitive ones are definitely the Fall and the Winter. There is nothing like experiencing the changing leaves during a New England Fall. This is the only time of year where tourist buses frequently pass through campus. Winter is the season that students bring up the most. For those who are not used to the snow and sub-zero temperatures, it is definitely difficult to survive. The school, as well as various student organizations, organize trips to outlet malls for students who need to buy more winter clothing. Most students would say that Winter is extremely cold and miserable. However, being a snow enthusiast, I loved every bit of it. You will never see such pristine, beautiful snow in a city. Since there is so little traffic in Hanover, snowstorms will blanket the campus and it will stay white for a long time. The best part of winter is the annual midnight snowball fight on the Green after the first snowstorm each year. Winter Carnival is also tons of fun. I definitely recommend participating in the building of the humongous snow sculpture each year.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: D-Plan Allows for Flexibility and Creativity – Dartmouth's D-Plan makes it unique from other schools. We have a quarter system of about 10 weeks each and students can design their residence plan according to when they want to be on campus taking classes or when they want to be off for a study abroad program or doing something else like internships or volunteer work. The big drawback is that each term become very fast-paced and intense. However, the D-plan also gives you a lot of flexibility in making your own college experience. You can get quite creative with what you make of your off-terms!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You can find wireless availability almost anywhere on campus, so most people carry their laptops around with them. However, the libraries do have several computers if you need to use them. Still, it is handier to bring your own computer, especially if the library is crowded. There are printing stations at several places on campus, including many dorms, so having your own printer can help but is not completely necessary.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: In the Middle of Nowhere – Dartmouth is located in Hanover, NH. This is a rural town about 1.5 hour from Manchester and 3 hours from Boston. There really isn't much in the town except for the campus. So, most of the activity takes place in the college itself.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Free Advance Transit Buses – The free advance transit buses are the most convenient option of getting to nearby smaller places. There is Dartmouth Coach to go to Boston and New York but its quite costly.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Winter Is Awful, but Everything Else Is Great – Autumn here is gorgeous, but it quickly transitions into an unforgivingly frigid winter that spans from October to April. It snows until it is too cold to snow, then things are just miserable because the temperature is in the negatives and everything outside is drab. Only the die-hard winter sports people like to stay on campus during winter term. Spring is slow coming and very often cloudy and rainy. For every three cold, overcast days we'll have one warm, sunny day. Summer gets somewhat hot- hot enough for swimming anyway. It still rains a lot during the summer, though, so it can get pretty muggy. Back to autumn and the breathtaking burst of colors that blushes the surrounding deciduous forests. I've never seen leaves like this.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Gorgeous Campus – The college spends a lot of time and money ensuring that the grounds and the buildings are kept in top condition. 
The athletic center is top of the line and open for extended hours during the school week that make it easier for busy students to work in their work outs.
The student center (Collis) is always buzzing with some interesting activity (or twelve!) and everyone that works there is friendly and helpful. The cafe has the best made-to-order stir fry and omelets on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It snows and rains a lot which makes going out a hassle but students become used to it.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Good on Campus, Not So Much Off Campus – The college works really hard to provide alternative social scenes to the drinking atmosphere (which is super easy to avoid and there is no pressure to join it) and the college does a really good job.  Anything from arts to athletics to more academic work, there is a club for it.  And, if there isn't a club, you can start one really easily.  Off campus is a small town, so not much is offered.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love this college, as do most of the people I talk with.  Dartmouth is a best kept secret, we feel.  It's an Ivy league with enormous opportunities, in a great area (New England is really gorgeous, especially during the fall) and is community-based.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not Bad – Frats and affinity housing has parking, but you'll likely end up in A-lot, which is over a mile away from the closest dorms.  No one drives to class, so it's not that irritating.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: One Way: Buses – Hanover is not very difficult to navigate on foot, as it is an extremely small town. The free public transportation/bus system runs on weekdays at reasonable times but not on weekends, which is sometimes an inconvenience. However, the Dartmouth Coach charter bus provides a clean and reliable way to travel to major cities such as Boston and New York.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Well Kept, Quiet, Social, and Brand New – The school just got a new gym in 2008 for all varsity athletes, which freed up TONS of space in the student gym, which is free if you go to the school. The treadmills and elliptical machines in there have built in TV's which is awesome because you can count on people to join you in the gym to "workout" i.e. watch grey's anatomy. The student center is great with tons of couches, a random piano that people will play on, 5 different flat screen TV's and tons of other fun things like a dancing center, pool tables, free coffee and tea in one of the student cafes, its really fun to just hang out around campus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: All Student Are Required to Have a Laptop – The school requires all students to have a laptop so finding a computer is not hard. All of campus is wireless and for some reason if you do not have your computer the computers in the library are really nice, modern, and accessible.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I am concerned about my future opportunities, mostly because it has been difficult to secure worthwhile internships.  Freshman summer internship opportunities were limited both by limited exposure to companies to apply to, since there is no on campus career fair in the engineering school and by the limited course background.  Sophomore internship was difficult for the above reasons adn additionally because the trimester off during sophomore year that is required is not when many companies hire college interns - they do it in the summer when all the Dartmouth sophomores have to be at school.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Dartmouth has tons of connections/networks. Also, it's name is super prestigious. Finding jobs is a breeze with campus services/recruitment
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Alumni networking is great. There are many career centers and fairs that help students get to the next level.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Dartmouth has quite a name, and the D-Plan makes it so that there's not competition for internships or employment during the year. A lot of people have gotten connections and work through Dartmouth alumni as well.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Dartmouth helps you get an internship and get into grad school
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It is very easy to get internships, fauculty will help you but you have to approach them first.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Finding a job or internship can be fairly easy through the college especially through the Center for Professional Development.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Unless you're an econ or business major, it seems much harder to get help from the college with finding internships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: One of the most accessible and helpful alumni networks
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The alumni network is phenomenal
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: A Dartmouth degree is a permanent foot in the door practically everywhere. If an alum works at a firm you'd like to work for; you're basically guaranteed at least an interview.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Dartmouth's alumni network program is very strong.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received an awesome financial aid package. It was the best offer out of all of my schools.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Friendly staff and personal attention
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I went through Dartmouth paying a minimal amount for school. This is a rare happening for international students. Dartmouth has the money, you just gotta ask for it.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: While I have yet to graduate, I think that the experience I am looking for is a difficult one (politics).
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Dartmouth financial aid is amazing, but the process is annoying for sure.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Trips and orientation are often some of students favorite experiences here.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Financial aid is a necessary headache for many students. While the Financial Aid office is inconvenient (they close at 4pm), the officers are fairly helpful.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I was quoted a price estimated at early decision time which greatly increased after committing.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The college is paying everything for me. The only thing is a standard summer contribution cost that all students pay before the start of fall term. I thought I wasn't going to have enough for books, but there is an interlibrary loan system with the other Ivies and Ivy equivalents, and you can easily find your textbooks through there.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Ended up with great financial aid but had to fight for it a little.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Students who graduate from Dartmouth are INCREDIBLY sought after by employers!! It is very easy to find jobs and internships and graduate schools will be all over you. Career services center is great and help a lot too! Really strong alumni network that is very true to the school and will help you a ton!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Lots of financial aid available. Need-blind admissions!!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid is good, but it could be better. Also, they say no loans but I have to take out loans anyway.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: From the graduating seniors I know, I can tell that a degree is very valuable. Personally, I just finished my first year, but I landed an internship through the public policy department's connections with alumni.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid Dartmouth provides is not as substantial as some of its competitor schools, however, I still receive quite a bit of aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The school has a lot of money, and it's financial aid is pretty good. Compared to other Ivy's, it's not the best. Our costs are really high, and we spend lots of unnecessary money on administration. Those who really need aid get it, and I think that the middle class gets the short end of the stick.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Dartmouth was extremely generous with my financial aid.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Be careful, the first year they offer a generous package, but it is not guaranteed afterwards.  I had to scramble for funding in my senior year and was forced to take out more loans than I expected.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Well Dartmouth College is not known to give out extremely generous scholarships.  In my case, I was accepted into Harvard University with an extremely generous offer.  Due to an honor system between all of the Ivy League schools, Dartmouth matched my scholarship and I was set to come to Dartmouth.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received financial aid throughout my time at Dartmouth, and it was not a hassle for me, but I did have many friends who felt like they were being haggled by the school regarding aid/payments.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: ROTC is hard work but if you want to go into the military, it's worth it!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There's a large endowment, and most students are given the aid they need to attend.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a decent amount of financial aid, but the process was excruciating, with financial aid officers nitpicking every detail and counting every asset as liquid money. Moreover, the financial aid package includes loan - which are less than helpful.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Since it is need blind it is unique and something that is really important since your financial aid is not a factor into getting into the school
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Need Blind Acceptance! Dartmouth is one of 10 or so schools that is need blind in the admission process, even for international students. On campus jobs for those who need them are easy to find and need-based scholarships, which will be the same at every Ivy, are usually more than other schools can offer.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Stingy Stingy Stingy – financial aid office will try to take every penny from you instead of helping you out
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Hooks You in the First Year, Throws You to the Wolves Every Year After – Dartmouth tries to attract good students by providing relatively generous financial aid the first year, but every year after, the financial aid office drastically reduces the aid provided, using shady and non-transparent clauses to explain their actions.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Got Nothing. We didn't qualify for need-based, and the Ivy league does not do merit.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Free Ride! Dartmouth promises to make it possible for any admitted student to be able to attend Dartmouth.  In fact, I actually get paid to attend.  Financial aid is based solely on need, but it's a very easy process.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Just Fill Out the Papers – The process was not difficult for me at all, and I received the financial aid I needed to not have to take out a loan my first year.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Helpful & Understanding Fin Aid Office – My financial aid situation is unique.  My parents fall into that weird middle-class bracket where we don't make little enough to receive tons of aid but we also don't make enough to pay for everything with ease.  With that being said my freshman year Dartmouth was great about comparing packages I'd gotten from other comparable schools.  They helped a lot and made sure I didn't have to pay as much as the federal government suggested.  This year I've gone into their office a few times and it's been a breeze each time - they saw me quickly, answered all my silly questions & explained the process step-by-step. The only reason I'm giving a B+ as opposed to higher is because I wish I could get more money.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Hanover does not allow chains.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Same things over and over again. You got your Pizza, Chinese, Thai, Indian, Tapas, Mexican, American Comfort Food and Coffee place. and Subway and Starbucks. I guess you don't need much else.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: It's expensive and the swipe situation is not super practical but the school is getting better about it: now some of the  extra DBA rolls over. Plus, there is really nothing else to eat around hanover. Even if you manage to get on the off-campus meal-plan, you have to navigate the amount of time shopping + cooking for yourself takes in conjunction to how much time you need for academics. The meal-plan is not amazing, but it is pretty convenient.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is definitely great quality, but it is damn expensive.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food is great and there's a lot of variety, but it is ridiculously expensive.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are only a handful of restaurants in town, but a good variety. A number of them are quite expensive, and none offer student discount. That being said, you can still find good food at a decent price.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Food on campus is generally pretty good quality, though the limited options means dining halls are often overcrowded. The meal swipe plan works well for some people, and so much for others. While it allows you to get an all-you-can-eat meal at Foco, you can't use your swipes to buy coffee or baked goods at KAF.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: I think that more should be offered through DBA at local spots.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining areas are cool.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: As I mentioned in my general review about Hanover, everything is pretty effing expensive! However, if you have the money and time, I totally recommend visiting Jewel of India, Boloco, and Morano Gelato. I'm also throwing in the Oriental Wok Express, which is in West Lebanon, but every college student loves Chinese and I can tell you right now their food is fantastic. Anyway, Jewel of India is an awesome family-run restaurant a bit aways from the Green in the center of Hanover. They have a website, will deliver anywhere within three miles of the restaurant, and offer a 10% student discount. All of the items on their menu are traditional Indian recipes and everything is delicious so it wouldn't hurt to try something new at this place. There's even a vegetarian option and if you don't finish everything, you can get take-out boxes. In terms of location, Boloco and Morano Gelato are much more centralized and less of a walk from the green. If you want a delicious burrito fast, go to Boloco. If you want to satisfy your ice cream craving but are sick of the flavors offered by Foco, go to Morano's. Both places are also more casual than Jewel of India so they're a good place to grab a quick bite to eat. Morano's is also right next to the Nuggest theater so you can go watch some cool films before/after your gelato treat!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is definitely a great variety of food if you know where to look! Foco, for example, may be the most expensive of the campus's dining options, but it's totally worth it. There are separate sections for people who are vegetarians or allergic to gluten and a huge stir fry/salad bar. Every week, the cooks also prepare different special recipes from around the world! But if the amount of different food and drink is too overwhelming for you, there's always pizza haha. And, of course, the dessert bar. Overall, even if some days it is a little lacking, Foco is awesome and the food is delicious. The Hopkins Cafe is a great place as well with a nice atmosphere. I say that mostly because it is in the Hopkins Center so there are a lot of cool shows going on that you should totally watch if you have the time and money. It's more quiet than Foco too so if you and your friends just want to chat for a bit, you should hang out there. Among other things, the cafe is also good for stocking up on snacks! There is stuff like candy, trail mix, dried fruit, whatever you want. If you're willing to walk a bit, you can also go to East Wheelock's snack bar too, which opens late into the night in case anyone ever wants a midnight snack.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
There is no student discount policy in place, which is a major bummer, since the college essentially forces you to overpay for okay food on campus. 

There are about 15-20 restaurants off campus, including an Indian food restaurant, an East Asian food restaurant, and a burrito place, all of which are at least decent. There are 4 or 5 pizza places, some of which are pretty good.

The only place open late-night is Everything But Anchovies (EBAs), which is a student favorite for delivery and late night.

If you're looking for groceries, there is an upscale grocery store (The CO-OP) near enough to campus that walking isn't ridiculous (though it's not convenient). If you want a larger and cheaper grocery you'll have to take the bus (hourly on weekdays) ten minutes to West Lebanon or find other transport. 

The only chain restaurants are a Subway, a Starbucks, and a Dunkin Donuts. Others, including Five Guys, Chili's, and plenty of others are a 10-minute bus ride away.

The best off-campus restaurant in Hanover (in my opinion) is Salt Hill Pub, a cheapish bar & grill type of place with plenty of seating, a shuffleboard table, and live music, karaoke, and trivia nights.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Haven't really explored a lot of these options, but that's a lot of Asian cuisine, as well as other ethnic group cuisine.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A few really good restaurants right down town but they can be expensive. Morano gelato was ranked one of the best in the country, Molly's is always popular, some decent ethnic food, and 3 guys BBQ is great. Also some really good places to eat further off campus if you have access to a car.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lots of different options, high quality of food!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Very nice various different types of restaurants in walking distance of the campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The actual food is good. The system of buying it is not. If there is one thing that unites practically all Dartmouth students, it is that they dislike DDS.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The quality of the food served in the dining halls is decent, however, the meal plan can be quite frustrating. The current meal plan compels students to eat almost exclusively on campus from fear of wasting an already-paid-for meal plan.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Off campus dining is insanely good. From upscale (Pine) to cheap and greasy (Orient, C&A Pizza) there are something like 12+ options and they're all good.  They have to be because land in downtown Hanover is so expensive.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
I loved the dining halls on campus. They were pretty good about having a variety of options, especially for people with special dietary requirements.

When I first came to school, I had had surgery and needed to be on a liquid diet for a few months. The school worked with me to ensure that I had access to certain foods, and also being a vegetarian, there were always delicious vegetarian/vegan options on campus. Certain dining halls and cafes also stayed open late to ensure students could get food late at night while studying or after being out at a party.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are a few restaurants in town, mostly sit-down places or late-night establishments. The prices vary from inexpensive to expensive, and there are happy hour specials, but no real specials/discounts for students. There are more options in the next town over which is about a 10-15 minute drive, but those options are more fast food restaurants, which are inexpensive.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review:
dining halls around campus are great
lots of options
easy meal plan flexibility
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Small town means very few off-campus eating options. We have 4 dining halls and 3 cafes on our very small campus. Lots of options and food is available from 7 am to 2 am everyday
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Though many complain, as a picky Vegetarian who sometimes eats kosher I never have any trouble finding food. The dinning hall is pretty good quality with some variety, and the other cafes provide some options and in some cases restaurant quality food. On the other hand, the 1st term dining plan is a rip-off.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bad pizza, late night ok pizza, fair/good pizza, a good Indian restaurant, a Thai place, a Chinese place, 2 bakeries, a Subway, a Burrito place, a fancy restaurant, a medium-fancy restaurant, and Italian restaurant, and Lou's (a dinner that is a campus legend.) These are the only eating establishments in Hanover.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Although the main dining hall can grow out very quickly, it still does try to switch it up and provide new and interesting options at least a couple times a month.  There are other dining places like Collis and The Hop that provide made-to-order food and always have specials that are actually pretty good.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The surrounding area severely lacks a variety of dining options. There is essentially only one small street for off campus dining (Main St.). The prices are average, but they do not offer discounts to students. The one perk about Dartmouth is that the college encourages students to take professors out to lunch. The college will give students a modest stipend so they can take a professor of their choice to any restaurant in the area--a very valuable resource to get to know a professor better.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: 3 good dinning halls and also good places to snack in the library. KAF just opened in the library, really great for late night coffee and snacks
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: I've lived in a small town before, so I was pretty impressed with the number of restaurants that Hanover supports.  That said, if you come from any sort of city, you'll probably find it a bit lacking.  But there are a few very good restaurants within walking distance from campus, and lots more  to choose from if you have a car.  Favorites include Molly's, Murphy's, Salt Hill Pub, Jewel of India, Lou's, Yama, Canoe Club, The Orient, and Boloco, which offer grill food, pizza, pasta, bakery food, Indian, Chinese, Japanese, and burritos.  There's not much open late at night, but EBA's (pizza) delivers until 2:10 am.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: great selections on campus and off.  They just need to get a Chipotle
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The good is very good on campus. Foco is my personal favorite (although it can get old). Athletes go to the Hop for greasy fried food, and Collis is nice for a smaller meal, whereas Foco is all you can eat. There are plenty of healthy options for those of us who like to be conscious of what we eat.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a few good restaurants - Molly's, Murphy's, Market Table, Pine. However, the options are very limited (those are basically the only places). Needless to say they get old REALLY quickly.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a few places to eat off campus such as EBA's, Yama, Salt Hill, Molly's, Boloco. However, most student groups will frequently order take out for meetings, so there is a good chance you will exhaust the off-campus dining options. The prices vary but they are not all that economically-friendly. Keep in mind, Hanover is a small town and there is not much there.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
Food at Dartmouth is generally decent, with some dining halls, and some meals usually being better than others.  Some things are always a hit, while others vary day-to-day.

There are three major dining halls at Dartmouth: Fifty Three Commons (FoCo), Collis, and the Hop, as well as several other, smaller, places to eat (Novack, King Arthur Flour...).  FoCo is all-you-can-eat, while the rest are pay-per-item.  Food varies from place to place, and sandwiches, pasta, stir fry, grilled food, and cookies are staples of a Dartmouth student's diet.

Meal plans include a certain number of "meal swipes," which give you entry into FoCo, and a certain number of flex dollars that can be spent at any of the others.  Meal swipes can be used to buy a certain dollar amount worth of food at any of the other dining halls (the value varies by time of day), and flex dollars can be used to buy entry into FoCo (again, price varies by time of day).  These options are generally not worth it.

Some of the best deals include the dinner special or burger special at the Hop, stir fry or the pasta dinner at Collis, or Sunday brunch at FoCo.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's pretty much something for everyone, but because Dartmouth is a small school, the options aren't limitless but they are varied. Foco is an acquired taste for most students because it's the biggest dining hall on campus, but it does have the most options. Collis is a great place for lunch with fresh stir-fry and pasta choices. For late night, Novack Cafe is open until 2am, and for coffee, we have a King Arthur Flour cafe in the library, which is a campus favorite. The meal plans are improving as the years go on, but I suggest leaving the 20 for freshman year.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: For such a small town, Hanover has a lot of restaurants.  There is a wide variety of foods and prices, but everything I've eaten off-campus has been really good.  Places like Boloco and EBA's deliver to the dorms, which is convenient for those who don't want to walk.  But nothing is far from campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I gave off-campus dining a B simply because there are not many options within walking distance.  However, the options that you do have (Lou's, Molly's, EBA's, etc.) are very good and are within a reasonable price range.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Collis is the best dining option, the food is amazing, but there isn't too much variety. The Food court is next, it has lots of variety, but in my opinion it is not that good. And the meal plans are lacking a bit.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are good places on campuses like the dining halls and if one wants, there are many small restaurants around.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The off-campus food is tasty, and there are a variety of cuisines, however there is only one restaurant of each type. It's easy to eat at every single place twice by the end of your freshmen year. So by senior year, you're pretty sick of the off-campus options. Also, every single restaurant is way over-priced. You can't get any meal at any restaurant for less that ten bucks. Even something as simple as salad or chicken tenders and fries.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The Food Is Great – Alright, so the food on campus is really good. We have three main dining facilities: FoCo, Collis Café, and the Hop. FoCo is all-you-can-eat and has excellent pizza, burgers, chicken, and a huge salad and dessert bar everyday. It rotates the other mains dishes every day (homemade station, international station, and a vegetarian station). Collis has incredible pasta, stir-fry, salad bar, and omelettes every day, and a bunch of healthy options. You only pay for what you select. The Hop is near the gym, and has a delicious grill selection (quesadillas, burgers, fries) and a deli. Delicious. SO, food is great, but the dining plans are not. It's kind of expensive and sometimes you feel DDS (Dartmouth dining services) are ripping  you off, but it really isn't that bad.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pretty Good! okay, so Hannover isn't exactly known for its off-campus dining… But I think it's pretty darn good! You have so much variety, there're some places that are cheap, others that are expensive, great places to go with friends, great place to go to parents, and the pizza joint that is open until 2 AM, for drunken escapades. We love it here, there are always places to go, and the local atmosphere is so friendly.  also dirt cowboy is great for coffee!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dartmouth's campus dining has fallen on hard times.   The Dartmouth now bares the dubious honor of being the only Ivy League school to have been sued for its poor services and outrageous meal price changes.   The food is dramatically overpriced (one student was famously billed $60 for a chicken sandwich) and the only thing more unbelievable than poor quality is the stunning lack of variety. To make matters worse the dining schedule is beyond belief.   Food must be consumed at weird hours and carry out options are subject to convoluted rules and a lawyer couldn't understand.   If you care allot of but food, or hate being screwed over, Dartmouth is not the place for you.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: After they renovated Foco and got rid of the amazing Homeplate and Foco and replaced it with a large all-you-can-eat dining hall, food definitely took a nosedive. They make an effort to bring in ethnic cuisine, but often don't do an amazing job at it. Food definitely gets pretty boring towards the end of the quarter.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Decent but Hard to Eat Healthy – The title pretty much explains it. Its also fairly expensive and the meal plan options have recently been changed to benefit the college financially while hurting the eating habits of the students. But students are protesting and moving to get the changes reversed.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Good Food, Bad Value – Although there are a few places on campus to eat, there is only one place i like to go. With the meal plan from fall term, I ended up having to pay dining services $100 because I exceeded my flex-dollar allowance. The food is great at The Hop, but the price is outrageous.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Not Too Much to Rave About – There aren't too many options in town and the options aren't very diversified.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Good but Not Great – The food isn't bad by American standards (it's probably pretty good, actually), but as an Asian-American who grew up in a household eating Asian food, I get bored quickly with what's offered here. Also, the meal plan required for freshmen is annoying and a waste of money; using 20 meal swipes a week is not economical.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bland and Repetitive – Same rotating schedule of meals every week with limited dining options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
Variety, but Gets Old. There are definitely a variety of dining options in the area that cater to most food cravings.  There's Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Thai, Indian, "American." There all a little over priced, but not too bad when you consider the isolation of the campus. 

The food selection gets old though after while, but again that is due mostly to the isolation and the lack of more restaurant selections.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Lots of Variety – We have everything from local organic produce to chicken nuggets and cheeseteaks.  We have a bunch of different dining halls and they all offer different options.  There are also dining halls that are open for late-night food.  Everyone always has a meal plan.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Not Bad – At Dartmouth there are 5 places to eat, one of which is little more than a cafe. The other 4 are good, although there isn't a ton of variety in the menus. Overall it is pretty good until the end of the term when you've had the same thing over and over again for weeks. The dining halls are only close to one of the dorm buildings, so be ready for a bit of a snow hike during winter term.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lack of Variety – Hanover is a very small town, so most of the dining places are located centrally to campus. However, there are only about 5-10 places to eat off campus. That being said, they all serve fairly decent food (Molly's and Lou's being the best) but it gets repetitive having to eat at the same places off campus all the time.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining on campus is awesome.  I guess it has to be considering there aren't more than two student-friendly restaurants in town.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Surprisingly Large Variety – Considering Hanover's small size, the town has a remarkable variety of dining options. Prices range from the classy Canoe Club restaurant to Thursday night pizza and beer specials at Ramunto's. Great ethnic food is also available from Mai Thai (Thai), Yama (Japanese), and Gusano's (Mexican). Student favorites include Ben & Jerry's and Everything But Anchovies, which delivers until 2:15 AM.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
...for such a small suburban town. The options for off-campus dining, while not numerous, are nicely varied. Just don't expect any brand-name chain eateries to roll into town any time soon; Hanover makes a point of keeping those out.

The local feel to the restaurants is great, however, and while my personal favorite is probably Yama (Korean entrees/Japanese sushi bar), others like Jewel of India and Gusanoz are other reasonably priced and palatable ethnic options. For those who like their eating out more American, there is a wide variety of those too, from Canoe Club (refined casual, expensive) to Ramunto's and EBA's (your typical American pizzas, wings, etc., cheaper).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
Dining Places and Cost – There are several great restaurants a block away from campus. Murphy's, Lou's, EBA's. These range from a cheap meal for 7 dollars to an expensive dinner for $20. There are at least two Chinese restaurants, and typical American food. 
There are also ice-cream...and just about everything.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Only issue with housing has to do with the Dplna, where students leave campus for 1 trimester during their sophomore year.  This requires a lot of moving in and out of dorms.  it also means that during the sophomore year, your friends that you made during Freshman year are never all at school on campus at the same time.  Each trimester that you are at school during sophomore year, people that you care about, or are learning from or working with are constantly coming and leaving campus for several months at a time and it is a bit of a negative.  Sophomore summer when everyone is there again is really nice.  Unfortunately, then in Junior year, people start leaving again to do a semester abroad.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I live in a good house with really good facilities (newest).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I lived in Choates and sometimes the heater wouldn't be working. In the spring there were no AC coolers and it was very hot in the dorms. Sometimes the window wouldn't open all the way.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Fayerweather mid, where I am living, is one of the best dorms on campus. It is decently close to my classes. However, the River cluster is quite far away from everything, and some of the dorms are not very spacious.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Lots of choices and living and learning communities to choose from.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing option for Freshmen varies a lot in terms of quality. I lived in Choates during freshmen year, and that is considered the one of the worst, but all in all, it's really no that bad if you don't spend too much time in your room. There are freshmen dorms such as McClaughlin that has elevators, snack bar, and very new and spacious rooms; it was built recently. However, the housing system is changing, and all undergrads are now assigned to certain "houses" randomly, kinda like in Harry Potter. There is the Allen House, North House, South House, West House, East Wheelock House, and School House. If you don't like random selection, you can also apply to live in living learning communities, LLCs.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshmen dorms are a bit tough to deal with but other dorms are more tolerable. Space is not a huge issue.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is really a mixed bag and your experience truly does depend on where you live.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Depends on where you live and which buildings you have most of your classes
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Beautiful campus with great options
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I'm in McLaughlin, some of the newest and nicest dorms on campus, in a spacious one-room double. The room is perfect and I really don't wanna leave it at the end of the year (it's honestly better than my room at home and most hotel rooms), but there are very few bad housing options on campus (besides, perhaps, the River).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Great experience living in a community house (Cutter Shabazz), my family for 3 years.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Amazingly huge dorms, the worst dorms on campus are still miles better than many of the best dorms at lots of other schools.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I personally live in what's considered the "worst" freshmen dorms on campus, but even these aren't bad - while the rooms are small, the great community more than makes up for the lack of space
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I'm in the nicest dorm for freshman, so I can't complain.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Moved almost every term due to the D-Plan (off terms). Dorms are clean, custodians are nice. Moving can be a pain but everyone is helpful. I love how open the living spaces are. No sign-ins or guards, so you can easily visit all your friends. All of them are convenient and close because the campus is small.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Definitely better than on-campus housing if you are willing to brave the winter on the way to class. The freedom is worth it for sure.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Campus housing is pretty great granted there is really not much else available except for greek/society houses and off-campus houses. It's clean, well taken care of, somewhat spacious depending on what lottery number you get and good in terms of location. The lottery system is rather hectic but manageable.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Although I've never lived off-campus, plenty of my friends have apartments off-campus. The rooms are ok, but they are basically dorms off-campus with more freedom. Same quality (perhaps slightly depending on the place).
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living off campus is costly and competitive, which is ironic given the extremely low quality of options available. Landlords range from inaccessible to crazy, and most apartments are small, dirty, and expensive.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: There's a huge disparity between the good and bad housing clusters on campus. While modern buildings like East Wheelock and McLaughlin are beautiful, comfortable, and filled with social & study spaces, older buildings like the Choates and the River have few amenities.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I think it would be difficult to live on the river if you spend most of your time at the athletic facilities.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: If you search long enough, you'll always get your dream home just next to the campus
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is cool. You can get whichever choice you want  (if you survive the competition,of course)
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman housing is universally pretty great--much better than dorms I've seen at other colleges.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Not many students live off campus but if you want to there are a variety of options. Can be a bit expensive but still cheaper than the dorms most of the time. Not too hard to find. There are lots of houses that are passed down between students but they can be somewhat run down. If you want to pay more there are nicer options. All within walking distance of campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Wide range of freshmen dorms. Some are amazing while others are pretty bad. It all depends how lucky you get and what is important to you in a dorm (proximity to classes, good social life, or cleanliness/quietness). Upperclassman housing is generally worse for sophomores but gets significantly better after that. One great thing is that almost everyone lives on campus or within walking distance at least so the campus has a good social atmosphere. Housing is a bit overpriced but so are most things in Hanover. Room draw can be frustrating especially because of the D plan.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you want it you can get it but the on-campus housing options are fantastic so there is little reason to live off-campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Fantastic housing, great dorms, great people!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living in a dorm like Fahey-McLane is comparable to a hotel, however, the Choates are quite outdated.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing really varies at Dartmouth. There are some beautiful houses with spacious rooms and clean, working facilities (bathroom and kitchen) but there are also others that are very badly looked after, where students are paying bills unworthy of the house. The problem is that very few landlords own most of the off-campus property, so they end up having a monopoly.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It is what it is.  You don't need off campus housing because the dorms and greek houses are great to live in, but if you really want to live off campus it's there.  One universally hated landlord controls something like 60% of real estate in town and is under investigation by the FBI.  Perhaps things will improve if she's arrested.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: With two exceptions, the dorms are all beautiful. Many are new and those which aren't are picturesque colonial architecture (think fire places in rooms, though you're not allowed to use them).  Every freshman is put onto a floor with other freshman and usually that's where you meet your first close friends.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I never lived off campus--don't have much experience on the subject
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Some dorms are great and some are awful. The housing process is unnecessarily tedious, so off-campus housing is advantageous for many students (it also allows more meal plan freedom)
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I loved my dorms on campus! They were fairly spacious and in close proximity to classes and the dining halls. It was nice to have your own space on campus, though the housing process to get a "good" dorm was sometimes stressful.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review:
few off campus options
most live in greek houses or dorms
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
I have a single room- no complaints. I also live in the farthest dorm from campus, but if you have a bike, everything is fine. Most dorms are good- just DO NOT LIVE IN THE CHOATES, unless you like load parties 24/7. 
Here are the best freshmen dorms:
McLaughlin "Hotel McLaughlin"
Fahey-McLane (central location)
East Wheelock (far away but great community)
Russel-Sage (Russel Rage)

Here are the worst:
Choates (noisy and old)
River Cluster (far away and old, but they have a great community)
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman floors become very tight, but there are definitely some dorms that are much better than others.  Some of the worst are also the farthest from campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing isn't terribly sought after
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Rent is super expansive! It would be very difficult to be a full-time student and work to pay rent and utilities. Parking would be extremely hard to come by! And if you do find parking it's usually far away from class.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Most of the housing is very nice. The "worst" place to live on campus would be the River which only houses freshmen.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living above Murphy's (there are apartments above the Murphy's restaurant) is probably the best, if not the only, off-campus housing option. Almost nobody lives off-campus though. The Dartmouth dorms are really nice, very convenient, and housing is essentially - though not formally - guaranteed for all 4 years.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I really like living on campus, the campus is small so any dorm (except the river) is a good location. The freshmen dorms always seem to be the best because people always have the best memories there.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Hanover is a small town, so off-campus housing is very close to campus and is definitely with-in parking/biking distance.  The price is about 600, give or take, per month and the conditions of the houses or apartments are in pretty good shape (landlords are also available if things go wrong).  There is parking available at your off-campus residence and if you hate walking you can alway buy a pass for on-campus parking.  Getting off-campus housing is readily available, a ton of people blitz (email) out about it and if you know someone in an off-campus house/apt then you are in.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Some Good Some Bad – I have only finished my freshman year, but I've heard about the other dorms as well. As far as freshman dorms, you just don't want to be placed in the River dorms because they are far away. But the majority of dorms are very clean, I never had a problem with the bathroom or with any bugs in my dorm. The Mclaughlin dorms are brand new so they are really nice. The other upperclassmen dorms are nice and in the middle of campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lots of Options – The housing is great on campus. There are lots of comfortable options (though in recent years, more freshman have had to live in one room doubles or two room triples than in the past). There is also tons of affinity housing which offers a closer community than the traditional dorm setting.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Not Too Bad – Dartmouth has a website where all the listings of available off campus apartments are. The closer you are to campus, the more the apartments seem like dungeons, but the farther you go and the better the deal.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: In a 2- Room Triple – A bit crowded and small - only 2 closets for 3 students  - they did ad a wardrobe which takes up a lot of the small space.. obviously a  2 room double which now houses 3 students
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Lucky to Get a Single – if you get a single, you're in good shape. otherwise, it sucks
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Luck of the Draw – Off-campus housing is pretty much out of the option as most of them are too far and inaccessible and the vast majority of the campus chooses to live on-campus. Freshmen dorm are assigned randomly and options get better as you progress through the years, but each year, the random number that you are given determines how good of a room you can get. With increasing sizes of incoming classes, Dartmouth has been facing a housing shortage but for the most part, on-campus living is not too bad. Especially if you're lucky enough to get the good numbers.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Available If You Want It – If you want to live off-campus, there are many options available.  It's a little cheaper than living on-campus.  On-campus housing is really nice though, so most students choose to live on campus.  Students who live on-campus can almost always get a single or an on-campus apartment (the apartments are four singles and two bathrooms with a living room and a kitchen).
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Costly, but Worthwhile Experience – As a freshman who must live on campus, I do feel that Dartmouth holds a monopoly on our dorming fees. It costs the same for two people in a double as it does for a person in a single, so a double is basically worth twice the rent in the single, and a triple is worth three times, although the square feet area of the rooms are not proportional to the price. However, when living in dorms, floormates are bound to become close like family, and it is a wonderful feeling to bond with everyone and have a solid set of friends that will be there no matter what.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The vast majority of Dartmouth's dorms are very modern and have fantastic social atmospheres. I live in one of the older buildings and I absolutely love it- people are always around and looking for something fun to do, and my room is much larger than the ones my friends at other colleges have. I really can't think of any way that Dartmouth's housing could be better,
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Close to Campus – The apartments are very close to campus and a great value. If you live off-campus you probably end up paying less than students who live on campus. However, off-campus living is not extremely popular so if you want it, it's always available, affordable, and convenient.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Almost All Houses – The off-campus housing options are usually a little bit cheaper than dorms, but they are almost always houses. The distance usually isn't a problem, especially since Dartmouth is pretty small.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Good, but on the Expensive Side. There are plenty of off-campus options around Hanover. However, most students choose to spend most, if not all, of their years living on-campus. The school has some of the best housing options you'll find anywhere. Usually, students only live off-campus during their Sophomore year, when, due to the housing priority system, it is more difficult to get one of the better rooms. Students also tend to live off-campus if they want to live with a large group of friends. Housing does tend to be surprisingly expensive for such a small New England town.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Huge Variety of Well-Kept Dorms – The best part of housing at Dartmouth is the sheer variety. We have singles, doubles one room and two room and three room, triples with one up to three rooms, four- and five-person suites, apartments, and affinity housing. Gender neutral housing is another really unique living style most commonly found in the East Wheelock cluster. New dorms like Fahey-McLane and McLaughlin are very spacious and well-designed although still with that generic dorm feeling. Older dorms like the Massachusetts cluster, although sometimes outfitted with aging utilities, are kept in good repair.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Social Atmosphere – The social scene revolves around fraternities and sororities, which does not suit all the students. Alternative social spaces are rare, and thus after two years a student can get tired of the same ways of having fun. However, with the amount of school work it is not that easy to find the time for fun.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living Off Campus Is Not Really Necessary – Hanover, NH is a small town that does not have a lot of housing options for students. If you choose to live off-campus, it CAN be cheaper, but it will also be farther and less convenient than living on campus. Dartmouth offers some very nice dorms, though, so most students(about 90%)choose to live on campus all four years.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Hate This Place – make sure you get one of the newly built dorms or you will be stuck in b-side old school housing
Housing.Author: College Freshman
